Coming into being in Europe in the 16th Century, the name "chapbook" didn't get coined until the 19th Century and was named after the men who sold them on the street, called chapmen. An offshoot of the chapbook, often sold for a penny and containing stories of crime, the supernatural, adventure, & romance were called Penny Dreadfuls. The western Dime Novel in the 19th Century in America is also an offshoot of the chapbook. The chapbook is typically saddle stitched or stapled. Yours will be sewn. 
A third book option is a blank sketch/notebook, coptic sewn so it will lay flat, with blank heavyweight paper and a kraft cover so you can embellish it however you wish.
I've included some samples of photographs I've made in that amazing place, and a haiku or two, just to wet your appetite. 
 

Point Lobos
 
I've turned part of my garage into a small bookbinding studio, alongside my matting and framing and general makin' stuff workspace. I want to put more of the artist (me) into the things I make and the handmade book lends itself to a more personal approach to the subject matter I have in mind for the book in this project and future books.
 

 
Impact of this project
The follow on effect of this project is me learning new skills, techniques, and methods to express my interpretations of the world in my art. There will be future limited edition handmade, hand bound books that are an entire artistic work, not just photos and words between a front and back cover. I have a couple pages of subjects/subject matter already in line for future book projects.
I've been a photography instructor and workshop leader for 20 years and fully expect to incorporate bookbinding in my classes when my skill reaches that level because I love passing on knowledge to others. I'm also an advisory board member for 2 high school commercial technical education photography programs in Boise and Nampa and active with those classes. I'm an Idaho Commission on the Arts Teaching Artist and conduct artist residencies in Idaho schools. This continuing education not only helps me grow but also the students who I interact with regularly. Your investment goes much further than you imagine. 
Artists are (or should be, anyway) always learning, experimenting, exploring, always interpreting what they see and experience, communicating through their art. I'm no different. My wildlife biology/science background, along with the experiences I've had traveling, give me a different perspective on the world. Not unique, but different. My hope is my art inspires, challenges, looks good and provides some enjoyment or maybe even a bit of enlightenment. I don't know if you collect art, simply enjoy viewing it, or like to support art, artists, and art making (which I thank you for, regardless of your preference). I don't know if this book will have any monetary value in the future or if you care if it does or not. But it's my gift to you, if you'll have it.
 

Point Lobos
 
411: My need, Your loot

Your support covers the workshop fee, my travel from Idaho to San Francisco and Carmel-By-The-Sea (I'm driving), the materials to create the chapbook, sketch/notebook, and the book and case for Point Lobos Dreaming (paper, book board, book cloth, end papers). This need totals $3000; $1800 for the workshop and travel, $1200 for the books. Shipping will be added when you stake your claim. Additional funds raised will be used to create stretch goals or add-on perks.
* Everyone receives a unique handmade thank you card. It could be something I sketched, a small cyanotype print, a woodcut print, a 4x6 photo, a bit of writing, or whatever I'm in the mood to create.
* Depending on your support level, you may also receive an 8x10 Point Lobos print, or the chapbook of artwork, writings, poems, & short essays, or the 8x10 handbound, blank, 120+ page, lay-flat (coptic sewn), sketch/notebook with a blank kraft cover for you to embellish for yourself, or the limited edition Point Lobos Dreaming book and case. Remember, I'm only making 20 of Point Lobos Dreaming, which will be 8x10, at least 80 pages, though probably closer to 120, made with heavyweight paper (still testing, but will be at least 50 lb or 229 gsm), likely with a flat-back binding versus coptic sewn.  And I wouldn't be surprised to see one or more handwritten pages in this book.
* Supporters will receive 1 or 2 updates on this project page per week until I leave for the workshop. While I'm at the workshop and Point Lobos, I will make daily updates on my progress and what's going on. When I return, the updates will likely return to 1 -2 per week as I'm getting everything organized and into production mode. I'll post less frequent public updates as well, to keep everyone on the same page, as it were. 
 

 
oops! But it's OK
What happens if the Fates decree I don't reach my goal? I'm committed to attending the workshop, and this project is set up with Flexible Funding, so whatever funding I receive will go to offset costs and/or purchase materials for prints and books. I will honor whatever support I receive. A couple previous projects on another platform were hampered because it was an all-or-nothing set up. Everybody lost. With Flexible Funding, I get something and you get something, even if it's not everything. Everyone who supports this project gets a personal thank you. Support me at any book level and you will receive a handmade book; a chapbook, a sketch/notebook, or the limited edition Point Lobos Dreaming. If you support me at the print level, you'll receive an 8x10 Point Lobos print. If it all goes south, I guess none of us gets anything, which would be a bum deal because I want to create these books and you probably want one, or two.
 


Point Lobos
 
I haven't done much crowdfunding for projects. As I mentioned, the last one I did was in 2016 for my book, The Ecology of Photography, which included a gallery of photos from a trip to the Isle of Skye in Scotland (now available on Amazon). It was a project I thoroughly enjoyed and I'm looking forward to the opportunity to do another.
I'm a full time photographer/artist. Projects like this inspire me, perhaps inspire others, and maybe makes some small impact in the world. But it's art, and art must be made and sent out into the wild to be its own thing. I hope you're inspired to support me in this project. I am grateful and appreciative of your support.
 


 
Risks & Challenges
What stands in my way? Every time I venture out to do something there are potential blocks and hazards: Weather, mechanical failure, economics, accident, theft, and other unforeseen emergencies. Lack of preparation and equipment/tools to complete the task is also a challenge. Everything is possible; it just takes money, right? That, and commitment, dedication, and persistence. I have the equipment needed to complete the project, and I will have improved skills following the workshop. I'm all set.
For the photography at Point Lobos, the weather is always a primary player in determining the level of challenge. I've photographed in all sorts of conditions at high elevation and north and south latitudes, in rain, snow, cold, heat, wind, insects. Comparatively, the central California coast in summer is a walk in the park. Weather creates mood, interest, drama, story. Clear blue skies are nice now and then, but for a photographer too much nice weather is difficult to handle. However it turns out to be, I will make the most of it.
Handmade books do take a little time to make. With my current experience level, it will take me roughly 20-25 hours to make each Point Lobos Dreaming book once the design work, image editing, and layout is completed, which I will do during the month of September. Making the book includes printing the pages, making the covers, stitching the signatures, finishing the book construction, building the book box (clam shell or slip case, not sure yet), and shipping prep. I estimate I will begin layout and design, along with image editing and processing, in early September. I will have the paper selected and tested by then, and ordered, along with other materials such as book board, book cloth, end papers, etc. for the number of books I'll need to make. The sketch/notebooks take about 1/3 the time, and I can work on those while parts of the Point Lobos book are drying or pressing. Chapbooks are the easiest and I can turn those out fairly quickly once the design work is done. What will take a little time with the chapbooks is if there is any "manual entry", like handwritten pages or drawing/sketching or cyanotype printing that needs to be done. 
 

Point Lobos
 
Those that know me know how persistent I am (some might even say bull-headed). I've encountered enough challenges in my travels and life in general that I know if some barrier is thrown up, just to power through or find another way around. So, I'm not worried about missing this opportunity or failing to perform.
 


 
Other stuff related to your support
If you love the idea of this project but can't support it now, that's ok. I appreciate your vicarious participation. It would really help if you could share the project link to your social media platforms and anyone you think might be interested. Greater success in numbers! Let me know where you've posted and I'll send a personal thank you for your assistance.

By claiming a perk, or making a contribution of support, you enable me to attend the bookbinding workshop, make photographs and writings for the book, design, print, bind, and ship the sketch/notebook and limited edition Point Lobos Dreaming book.
You don't need to claim a perk to make a contribution of support.
You can contribute a higher amount than the perk level you wish to claim.
The Money: $1800 is needed to attend the workshop and make photographs at Point Lobos. $1200 is needed for materials for the perks; photo prints, chapbook, sketch/notebook, Point Lobos Dreaming book and book box.
Don't forget you can use the share tools to share this project directly to Facebook, Twitter, or copy the project link to add to any email or post on a blog, etc. Click on the heart icon to follow the project and receive public email updates.

Thank you for your support

story:
Greetings! My name is Shaquille Quamae Hall. I am 18 years old, a high-school senior and getting ready to move on to college. I will be the first in my family to go on to a four year university! I need help getting a new camera and computer before I go.

Growing up I never had much and I never asked for much, although when I absolutely knew something would benefit me I chased after it- that's why I chased after Photography. This medium of story telling has saved me from my unpromising future in the streets of Detroit and has taken me to places I would have never imagined. This project not only will improve my proficiency in my art, but will also help in my spot in a lucrative and promising future.

Your donation will help me explore other ranges of photography, build a trustworthy base of equipment, create cleaner photographs/stories and finally offset some of the costs of college.

What We Need 

Funding: $3000 is the goal of this campaign. The actual cost of the items total to $3,150 although indiegogo takes 8%, which is 240, although I've been selling on Amazon and can cover the difference. Donations will go towards, along with other funds, one camera, one computer, shipping fees, award fees, and indiegogo processing fees- Adds up quickly right!?

You can donate as little or as much as you'd like, ANYTHING HELPS!

If my goal doesn't reach its full amount, I will transfer what I have raised to my checking account and save up until I can make enough money to reach the goal I set, I'm investing in this also, selling almost all of my old gear!

The Impact

At the end of the day, my dream is a part of me. Anyone who knows me will tell you the kind of person I am, and If you do not know me, then reach out and get to know me! Your contribution is a blessing whether it is $100 or even $1, the fact that you support me is all I appreciate!

Assurance

For all who back my project you will receive updates on the purchase , arrival and use of what will be bought in order to know where your money is going to. This also applies to your awards.

Risks & Challenges

If you contribute, YOU WILL get your award, although If I do not raise all of my funds it will set me farther from my goal. That is okay though because I am determined to please my backers and chase this dream.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some of you just can't contribute (and that's okay!), but that doesn't mean You can't help:

  • Make some noise with your close friends, families, and social networks by sharing and helping me reach out to the masses with my campaign!

story:
What's DIFFELARITIES?

DIFFELARITIES is a documentary photography project about the lives of people in the two eternal countries-competitors – the USA and Russia.

Relations between Russia and the US have been changing dramatically in XX-XXI centuries. They were allies, and they were in the process of global geopolitical confrontation; there were thaws and assistance as well as mutual accusations and sanctions. We know almost everything about stars, politicians and politics, the White House and the Kremlin and other stuff from the TV and the Internet, but what do we know about ourselves - who are we beyond the headlines?

People say that America is a country of immigrants. Russian immigrants are common in the US. A lot of Russians fled their “motherland” for different reasons: economic and political problems, personal issues, or they were just chasing the “American dream”…

Russia has been my home for 30 years and I’ve documented life in this country for a decade as a photojournalist. I've just immigrated to the US to start a new life. I've only been to the US once in 2015, and 3 weeks were enough to fall in live with the country, but not enough to understand it. To understand the USA and it’s people better and to find a new place to live, I plan to ride around the states on a bicycle, trying to answer some questions: What does the real America – beyond the headlines – look like? What is a Russian immigrant going to face in this new environment? How is my life going to change? While looking for answers to these questions, I will try to see the USA with an immigrant’s eyes and photograph what I see.

In the end of the journey, I will compare life of ordinary people in Russia and the USA through documentary photography. About 700 photographs from my decade of work in Russia have been already chosen, and that would be the first part of this project. During my journey around the US, I will also collect visual documents of people’s lives and build the second part of the archive. These two archives will help me bring up the picture and explore the questions – are Russians and Americans that different? Or do we have more similarities than we think? DIFFELARITIES is the project that will try to help find the answers.

To know more about me and to see more photographs from the Russian part of the project, visit diffelarities.com.

The Route

The “American part” of the project will start in Summer 2017. As I’ve already tried different types of vehicles in previous expeditions, this time I chose to travel around the country on a bicycle. Why? It’s the ideal method of transport for unhurried observation: its speed allows to see more details, to listen and to think more. A bike can go almost anywhere, unlike a car. A bike is cost effective. And it’s eco-friendly. A bicycle will help me meet more people and understand what the real USA looks like.

A route computed by Dr. Randal S. Olson (A Senior Data Scientist at the University of Pennsylvania).

The starting point of DIFFELARITIES is Washington, DC. The main goal of the trip is to visit as many states as possible to understand the country better. Luckily, I have found an “optimal route” through the US. This route was computed by Dr. Randal S. Olson (A Senior Data Scientist at the University of Pennsylvania). His work will help me visit almost 48 states, lots of towns, cities, and even tourist locations.

Goals

The main goal of DIFFELARITIES is to compare life in two countries - Russia and the USA - through documentary photography. To reach it, I have to cycle through 48 states, visit cities and towns and gather as much visual material as possible. The result of the expedition will be published on diffelarities.com, and after the final selections are made, I will start working on digital photobook, copies of which would be sent to my backers. I will also try work on getting an real-life exhibition and publishing a printed photobook. Stay tuned!

Funding

As long as the main expedition's vehicle will be a bicycle, and a tent will be my home, I will need not much money to make this expedition happen. Mostly, the money will be spent on basic things: food and bike maintenance.

I already have a great bicycle (thanks to my friends from Finland - Pelago Bicycles), a tent and all the other equipment for autonomous existence and photographing, as well as experience to live on the road and in the wild. The only thing needed is keeping the body running, so I can keep pedalling and photographing. The minimum is to raise money for the first 12 months of the journey. The plan is to spend not more than $20 per day for food, water and everyday needs. So, the minimum for a year of travelling is $20 x 30 days x 12 months = $7200. This will cover my basic expenses for food for 12 months. If you help me raise more money, I will also be able to stay online (pay for 4G internet) as well as cover some other expenses (like necessary bike parts - cables, brakepads, tires, chains, etc), as well as travel longer.

Of course, there will be unexpected expenses and in that case I will pick jobs in local cafes and bars, if lucky. This would not only be a rest from pedalling, but also would give me a chance to better understand everyday life, customs and habits of different communities of the US.

If this campaign doesn't raise it's goal, the expedition will be still a go. I will just have to change the plans and dates, and pick more jobs on the way.

Please, support DIFFELARITIES and help me bring it to life!

About Perks

As long as this is a solo expedition and I will be somewhere in the middle of nowhere most of the time, I can't promise that I will be printing, making and sending a big amount printed photographs, books, t-shirts and other physical objects. It's just impossible to make than alone. But I will have Internet connection and devices, which make life easier and more comfortable, so I can offer you guys:

  • Special thanks on DIFFELARITIES website and Instagram;
  • HI-RES digital copies of my photographs signed with a digital signature (so you can print them yourself and hang on the wall or just burn :));
  • A digital photo book. Before trying to publish a paper book, I will work on a digital photo book, which would be sent to my backers;
  • You can send me to a city of your choice in any of 48 states to photograph life of it's people (you and the city of your choice will be mentioned on Instagram in comments to photos and everyday videos about the expedition).

Please, have a look at the rewards list :) I know it's not much, but that's what I can really do and not let my backers down.

Updates and Feedback

If you want to know about the process of the expedition, if you want to ask any questions, or if you have suggestions, please, subscribe to @diffelarities on Instagram. You can also shoot me an email at diffelarities AT gmail dot com

Risks and Challenges

Previous expeditions were successful (you can learn about some of them here), although most of them were made in a team. But solo expeditions like this is always a bigger risk. Especially, taking in mind that the US is a new country for me, and the main vehicle is a bicycle, and the route isn't really short. Everything can happen on the road. But I believe, despite the challenges I'm going to face, no matter what, the project is going to be finished.

Although, there's a plan and a route, they can change due to circumstances: weather, my physical and mental condition, new encounters, seeking places to stay. There are no strict instructions to stick to, but there's always some room and a need for improvisation.

story:
Who am I you ask?

 

From a young age creativity has been encouraged in my life. I think creative work can help build, teach and brighten the world. What I hope to bring to people is the same sense of joy I had when I captured my photos. I choose to give attention to positive energy in my life and think it's important to share positivity where you can. My work feels very personal which is why I want to put a lot of attention in to the way it is presented; I want everyone to feel the life inside the images.

Being an artist in 2018 can have many different avenues. It has taken me some time but they way I feel best represented and most fulfilled is to share my art as a gift. I want people to engage and experience my work, not simply observe and digest, but to feel it, hold it, own it, share it, revisit it, bond with it. Much like an old family photo album, I want people to be able to connect with the books and feel part of my life.

 

What I need you ask?

Arts & Crafts are fun! But they cost money!

I really want to be able to hand-make these books but the cost of printing and materials is more than my freelance/barista wages can afford :(

Plan: The full collections will be on 8.5X11 plastic covered photo album pages. Single set books will be mounted on colored stockcard and some sets will only be available as part of the full collections. I hope to have everything printed and ready to send by the first week of June! Get orders in now and the sooner we hit the goal, the sooner I can get started!

 

How much is it you ask?

Donating:

$<7 - One (1) print per dollar

$7-10 - One (1) set per $7

$25-30 - One (1) collection per $25

(EX: Donate $43= (1) $25-collection, (2) $7-sets, (4) $1-prints

Donate $25= (3) $7-sets, (4) $1-prints OR (1) $25-collection

This campaign will work mostly as a preorder system. My website julianlavergne.com has order forms and details on the content of each different book available. Donate here and fill out the form to let me know which ones you would like and where to send them!

You can either donate first or place an order first but I will need a completed order form and donation before I can send your books. 

The completion of this project really depends on the amount of preorder sales I get, so the sooner more people donate, the sooner I can share with everyone. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're a little strapped for cash too, tell a friend, form an office pool, feature me on your Instagram stories! Spread the word!

My work feels very personal which is why I want to put a lot of attention in to the way it is presented; I want everyone to feel the life inside the images.Being an artist in 2018 can have many different avenues. It has taken me some time but they way I feel best represented and most fulfilled is to share my art as a gift. I want people to engage and experience my work, not simply observe and digest, but to feel it, hold it, own it, share it, revisit it, bond with it. Much like an old family photo album, I want people to be able to connect with the books and feel part of my life. What I need you ask?Arts & Crafts are fun! But they cost money!I really want to be able to hand-make these books but the cost of printing and materials is more than my freelance/barista wages can afford :(Plan: The full collections will be on 8.5X11 plastic covered photo album pages. Single set books will be mounted on colored stockcard and some sets will only be available as part of the full collections. I hope to have everything printed and ready to send by the first week of June! Get orders in now and the sooner we hit the goal, the sooner I can get started! How much is it you ask?Donating:$<7 - One (1) print per dollar$7-10 - One (1) set per $7$25-30 - One (1) collection per $25(EX: Donate $43= (1) $25-collection, (2) $7-sets, (4) $1-printsDonate $25= (3) $7-sets, (4) $1-prints OR (1) $25-collectionThis campaign will work mostly as a preorder system. My website julianlavergne.com has order forms and details on the content of each different book available. Donate here and fill out the form to let me know which ones you would like and where to send them!You can either donate first or place an order first but I will need a completed order form and donation before I can send your books. The completion of this project really depends on the amount of preorder sales I get, so the sooner more people donate, the sooner I can share with everyone.  Other Ways You Can HelpIf you're a little strapped for cash too, tell a friend, form an office pool, feature me on your Instagram stories! Spread the word!

story:
We are a group of 17 BA Photography students at Edinburgh College. In June we will be travelling down to London to exhibit our work at Free Range (at The Old Truman Brewery), an annual event featuring the work of graduates from across the country. Free Range is one of the biggest graduate exhibitions in Europe and by exhibiting there we can expect to have our work seen by many more people than a traditional degree show or independent exhibition. This is an opportunity to connect with other students and industry professionals and shape our future careers. 

We have been working hard all year to produce our best work so far and we would love to be able to take it to London, however, it is a very expensive trip for us - that's why we need your help!


What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise over £5000 to get to Free Range. Unfortunately we did not get any money from our College this year and we need to raise it all by ourselves. We have already successfully raised £3000, so we are looking to get another £2000 via  this campaign. 

We are paying for our accommodation and travel down to London but need your help with the cost of the venue hire and our prints. 


Please feel free to have a look at our work on our website and follow us on our other social media channels. This is a great opportunity for you to acquire unique work by an ambitious group of up and coming photographers. We hope you will enjoy our work and the special perks we will offer for your support. You can also help us out a lot by sharing our campaign on social networks. 

Links to all of our work can be found in the gallery section!

Our exhibition dates are: Thursday 18th - Monday 22nd of June 2015


Opening Night: Thursday 18th June 2015

Opening Times: Thursday  (Private views): 6pm - 10pm
                                       Friday - Sunday: 10am - 7pm 
                                       Monday: 10am - 4pm



Thank You!

story:
As many of you know, I have been wanting to combine the creative skills I have with the healing and intuitive work.

I have always, since I can remember wanted to tell the stories that do not get told. To go to the voiceless and give them a voice. And the main ways I wanted to do this was with words and image.

I feel I honoured much of this with some of my acting work and my writing also.

I really feel called to learn now about photography and I would like to invest in a good quality camera that at the basic rate costs around £300-£350. I have seen a photography course also that I would like to attend and would use any funds left over to pay towards that.

At the end of it I would like to start with portraiture and landscapes and see where the Universe takes me with this.

So what would you get?

Apart from my love and gratitude, I would happily take photos of any willing volunteers, yes of course! A pleasure!

And as it is my birthday soon I thought this would make the whole oh what can I get her thing so much easier. Instead of trawling the shops for a card or present you donate as much or little as you wish. It all adds up and will all help.

Thank you thank you thank you xxx

story:
Short Summary

As a writer, I've learned it is more potent to show a character's world, instead of telling the reader about it. How better to do succeed in this effort, than from behind a lens? Since my style of writing is often intensely visual, and I look for the stories in my photographic subjects, I felt it natural to combine the two into one book.

During a four year quest throughout the Ohio Valley's junkyards, alleyways and backyards, I sought to capture the beauty of vintage Detroit steel in photographs, preserve their stories that have evolved only through decades weathered patina, the labors of restoration. But, I wanted to create something more than a book of photography on classic cars and trucks. I chose to approach this effort with the perception that art is in the curve of metal, that it evolves in rust blooming under the elements, in the character of craft work we will never see the likes of again. These treasures are, unfortunately, disappearing forever. Theirs and our history alike, vanishes under a veil of overgrowth, or flattened in salvage crushers.

Although I cannot rescue or restore every vehicle lost to the scrapyards, I can preserve their stories, the hidden art of patina, chrome and curve, the gleam of restoration cruisin' the highway with the swagger of Saturday night. With this book, I can acknowledge old memories, introduce new generations to old- school cool and reveal art in unexpected places.


What We Need & What You Get

* To make Rodz N' Rust a reality will require $13,500. This sum covers publishing costs in order to produce a quality coffee table book of photography. All funding goes directly and solely to publishing with Acclaim Press.


*Rodz N' Rust is a coffee table gift book filled with over 300 unique images- 9x12, 160 pages.

Join author/photographer Sheri Wright on this tour of automotive excellence of yesteryear. During a quest throughout the Ohio Valley's junkyards, alleyways and backyards, Ms. Wright captured stunning photographs of vintage Detroit steel, whose beauty still endures decades after the patina has been tarnished by rust and the elements. More than a book of Photography, Rodz 'N Rust is a work of art, a piece of Americana captured for automobile-lovers from all generations.

If goal is not met, all funds will be pooled into other current and future fundraising efforts, which include, but are not limited to: Indiegogo's InDemand option, which automatically continue raising funds after my campaign ends,  art shows, sales of artwork and other automotive-related merchandise, corporate sponsorship queries.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

*The art of automotive manufacturing saw it's heyday after WWII. A surplus of steel and chrome was quickly put to use, creating automotive designs, the likes of which will never be seen again. This is our history, our art that once rolled across highways, cruised Saturdays nights and endless summers. Once it's lost to the scrapyard, it's gone forever. Rodz N' Rust is a dedication to this history, the lost art of steel curved into chrome, the stories etched in weathered patina, the labor of restoration, one backyard at a time.

*Having conducted two successful crowdfunding campaigns through Kickstarter https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/1624065865/tracking-fire-gathering-the-essentials and Power2Give http://power2give.org/kentucky/Project/Detail?projectId=5022, I'm confident that this campaign will also be a success.

*It's been said that we should do what we feel passionate about, that passion sustains commitment. I absolutely agree with this philosophy. In fact, I would take it to the next level by saying that a commitment to passion is a way of life. Do what you love. Live the way you love. Otherwise, life is just a job.

I find that what I love is the art that is all around us, hidden in the ordinary, waiting for us to see in a different perspective. Once I found a way to see differently, life profoundly changed. Rust was no longer metal in decay. It was art creating itself, blooming in sun. I hope to share some of that wonderment, so that other people might see past the ordinary, the nine-to-five, magic in the mundane.

Risks & Challenges

*As with any fundraising event, the outcome may not always be known.  What is certain, however, is the outstanding level of commitment, effort and experience to make this campaign a success.

*I have conducted two successful crowdfunding campaigns through Kickstarter https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/1624065865/tracking-fire-gathering-the-essentials and Power2Give http://power2give.org/kentucky/Project/Detail?projectId=5022 in 2014 for my non-profit documentary film, Tracking Fire. Additionally, to raise funds via other means for the film, I've produced several other fundraising events, hosted by various businesses and venues and private individuals. In combining a variety of fundraising resources from 2013-2015, I've raised 20k for this film.

*Establishing and maintaining a strong internet presence is one key to spreading the word about our art, projects and campaigns. I've worked tirelessly over the past ten years to build that presence, connecting with people nationally and internationally through a variety of social media platforms, such as Facebook, Twitter, Linkdin, Pinterest and Google Plus. I also maintain my own websites at www.scribblingsandsuch.com, Flickr and Behance.

Each of these resources, along with a vast email network, will be utilized to provide   Rodz N'Rust a strong marketing strategy for this fundraising campaign.

Additionally, local car clubs have been contacted for presentations of Rodz N' Rust to help bolster funding.


Other Ways You Can Help

I do understand that not everyone is in a position to contribute financially to fundraising campaigns. But, there are many ways people can still help make this fundraiser a success. And it's quick and easy.

* Help spread the word about Rodz N' Rust via social media and emails.

*Tell your friends.

*Use the Indiegogo share tools

And that's all there is to it.

story:
THE EXHIBITION EXPERIENCE

The War Zone Freelance Exhibition gives an exclusive look into the work and world of freelance journalists covering wars and conflicts in the Middle East.

Your donation to the War Zone Freelance Exhibition supports the exposure of freelance journalists dedicated to covering conflicts worldwide and contributes to educating the global public on where much of today's news comes from and the stories behind the freelancers in the field risking their lives reporting it.

The project is motivated by the desire to pay tribute and provoke debate on the important and consequential role freelance journalists play in bringing news out of conflict areas to the international public, often with little support, on their own expense and at extremely high risk.

The War Zone Freelance Exhibition 2016 is scheduled to begin in London atthe Frontline Club on January 28th and from this legendary venue, the team has planned a six month tour to gallery locations in major European cities including Paris, Berlin, Amsterdam, Copenhagen, and Barcelona. 

The War Zone Freelance Exhibition was founded in July 2015 and has since been published in various media and received great feedback from the Committee to Protect Journalists, Frontline Freelance Register, and other major journalist organizations from around the world. All of them are on board to share the WZF message and give informational and network support, however none have committed financially. 

Since the beginning, the War Zone Freelance Team has been self-financing their project and cannot continue without outside support. 


CREATORS

The War Zone Freelance Exhibition is made up by a team of international freelance journalists. 

American photojournalist Osie Greenway, Danish writer/ reporter Anne Alling, German writer/ photographer Benjamin Hiller,and Dutch videographer/ photographer Jeffry Ruigendijk have all spent considerable amounts of time in the last several years covering conflicts and humanitarian issues in Iraq, Syria, Lebanon, Israel, Palestine, among others. With both published and unseen material from war zones throughout the Middle East they propose a multi-faceted exhibition that will pull its audience deep into the reporting process and educate on both people affected by war in the region and the struggles and triumphs of working independently as a freelancer in a high-stakes vocation.


INSIDE THE EXHIBITION

When one enters the WZF exhibition, the visitor will immediately be overtaken by the ambiance created by the multi platform gallery presentation. The photography and videography gallery is where the audience can take the journey alongside the journalists by viewing images from remote battlefields throughout the Middle East while looking over personal items in display-cases used by the freelancers in the field that made reporting these stories possible. Items that each journalist find significant in their reporting along with other pieces of their stories that were obtained while reporting, including battle flags, uniforms, and other conflict-related artifacts. The viewers' mood is heightened by audio of war zone radio reporting that will play throughout the photo and video gallery. 

Connecting the photography and videography gallery to the interactive memorial will be a section dedicated to local freelancers who risk all in helping international media workers produce stories for global media outlets. With the use of their own media work and filmed interviews these talented individuals will share their personal stories of reporting on frontlines in their own countries and the life threatening hassles of freelancing as a local journalist. 

The final section of the exhibition will be a place to embrace the information obtained throughout the exhibit and witness the heavy costs of freelancing in war zones, by viewing WZF's memorial wall dedicated to freelance journalists killed or missing while covering conflicts in the Middle East during the last several years. The memorial will specifically highlight the local freelance photojournalist Molhem Barakat who was killed in Syria while covering battles in Aleppo. The memorial will be interactive with a message book for visitors that will be sent to the family of the fallen journalist, along with items for sale that raise awareness to the costs of reporting inside war zones.

FREELANCERS IN DANGER

During the past several years, threats towards journalists, especially those working in conflict areas in the Middle East, has increased drastically. Sixty-one journalists have been killed for reasons related to their work or have died while on assignment so far in 2015.
This year is expected to be the deadliest year ever for journalists. Freelancers with limited means, little backing from media companies, and often working alone in the field are further exposed to danger and account to the high number of deaths.


Syrian freelance photographer in his late teens Molhem Barakat was killed on December 20th 2013 while covering a battle at al-Kindi Hospital in Aleppo, Syria. Since May that year, he had been freelancing for Reuters who distributed dozens of his pictures around the world, some of them appearing in prestigious publications such as The New Yorker and The New York Times.


Selected photos from Molhem's portfolio will be displayed in the WZF interactive memorial along with the cameras he carried the day he was killed.

“Journalism was his whole life, it was his message to present real and honest photos. I ask you that you display his cameras in the exhibition so that the whole world can see it. My son’s blood is on those cameras”, Molhem’s mother writes to WZF about her son’s story being told at the War Zone Freelance Exhibition.


EDUCATIONAL PERSPECTIVE

Many exhibitions fail to tell the story behind the story of what it is like for journalists working in dangerous places. The WZF Exhibition will serve as a tool to educate on the profession of freelance journalism. The mobile exhibit is an ideal place for journalism students and media majors to learn about the freelance profession, a field that is often left out of college and university journalism curriculum. 

In each city we exhibit in, our goal is to highlight a local freelance journalist that has covered conflicts in the Mideast by sharing his/ her work and their experiences. The WZF journalists themselves will give lectures and hold Q&As to talk about their experiences and the impact of current conflicts in the Middle East.

In addition to highlighting local international journalist the freelancers and fixers from Iraq, Syria, and the Kurdistan region, who's work is displayed in the exhibition will come to elaborate in an open discussion forum on the challenges of covering war and conflicts as a freelance journalist in their home country. 

Speakers from international journalism organizations will attend for lectures to give statistical information and share their insight on the current state of freelance journalism.

FUTURE GOALS

After touring the Middle East exhibition for a six month period to major cities in Europe the WZF team hopes to purpose a second six month tour through North America starting in New York City and ending in Toronto where the exhibition media will be sold to raise money for CJFE's Journalists in Distress Fund.

Afterwards, the vision of the WZF team is to expand beyond the Middle East in order to cover more of the many conflicts happening today around the world, including Africa, East Asia and Eastern Europe.

The idea is to support and empower deep and authentic reporting by exhibiting local and international freelancers covering those areas. Through our exhibitions and online media strategies, we create a platform for both established freelancers and lesser-known talents to display their work and experiences to the public through the exhibition, our social media, and photo & video competitions.

HOW WE USE YOUR CONTRIBUTION

To cover the expenses of setting up the War Zone Freelance Exhibition and accomplish our 2016 six-month Europe exhibition tour we need your help!

The expenses include:

Printing & Publication of exhibition images,  posters, brochures, and exhibition catalogs. 

Exhibition supplies including projectors, display-cases, PA-system, and material for the interactive memorial.

Advertisement including press packages and urban & social media advertisement.

Travel & Accommodation for the WZF Team, local journalists & fixers, and attending speakers. 

Transportation of exhibit supplies throughout the Europe tour. 

SPREAD THE WORD

Another way to support the War Zone Freelance Exhibition is by spreading the word about our crowd funding campaign and get other people on board to support our project. 

You can find War Zone Freelance on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Vimeo and LinkedIn and don't forget the hashtag  #WZF16.

THANK YOU for helping us make this project possibleand we hope to see you, your friends, colleagues and family at the War Zone Freelance 2016 Europe Tour!

like for journalists working in
dangerous places. The WZF Exhibition will serve as a tool to educate on 
the profession of freelance journalism. The mobile exhibit is an ideal place for journalism students and media 
majors to learn about the freelance profession, a field that is often 
left out of college and university journalism curriculum.  

In each city we exhibit in, our goal is to highlight a local 
freelance journalist that has covered conflicts in the Mideast by 
sharing his/ her work and their experiences. The WZF journalists 
themselves will give lectures and hold Q&As
to talk about their experiences and the impact of current conflicts in the Middle East.


In addition to highlighting local international journalist the 
freelancers and fixers from Iraq, Syria, and the Kurdistan region, who's
 work is displayed in the exhibition will come to elaborate in an open 
discussion forum on the challenges of covering war and conflicts as a 
freelance journalist in their home country.  

Speakers from international journalism organizations will attend for 
lectures to give statistical information and share their insight on the 
current state of freelance journalism.





FUTURE GOALS





After touring the Middle East exhibition for a six
month period to major cities in Europe the WZF team hopes to purpose a second six month
tour through North America starting in New York City and ending in Toronto
where the exhibition media will be sold to raise money for CJFE's
Journalists in Distress Fund. 
Afterwards, the vision of the WZF team is to expand beyond the Middle East in
order to cover more of the many conflicts happening today around the world,
including Africa, East Asia and Eastern Europe. 
The idea is to support and empower deep and
authentic reporting by exhibiting local and international freelancers covering
those areas. Through our exhibitions and online media strategies, we create a
platform for both established freelancers and lesser-known talents to display
their work and experiences to the public through the exhibition, our social media, and
photo & video competitions.



HOW WE USE YOUR CONTRIBUTION



To cover the expenses of setting up the War Zone Freelance Exhibition
 and accomplish our 2016 six-month Europe exhibition tour we need your 
help!
The expenses include:
Printing & Publication of exhibition images, 
posters, brochures, and exhibition catalogs. 

Exhibition supplies including projectors, display-cases, PA-system, and material for the interactive memorial.
Advertisement including press packages and urban & social media advertisement.
Travel & Accommodation for the WZF Team, local journalists & fixers, and attending speakers. 
Transportation of exhibit supplies throughout the Europe tour. 


SPREAD THE WORD

Another way to support the War Zone Freelance Exhibition is by 
spreading the word about our crowd funding campaign and get other people
 on board to support our project. 
You can find War Zone Freelance on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Vimeo and LinkedIn and don't forget the hashtag  #WZF16.
THANK YOU for helping us make this project possibleand we hope to see you, your friends, colleagues and family at the War Zone Freelance 2016 Europe Tour!

story:
HEADING WEST - A Miron Zownir photo project 

(*please find German version below)

2016 - election year. No matter who wins the presidency, Clinton or Trump, America will be facing a new dimension of political and economic polarisation that will most likely split the Nation.

For many Americans it is a choice between bad and worse. In this time of uncertainty photographer Miron Zownir will visit the West Coast using his camera to visualise the eve of a new and potentially even bleaker era.

Every voyage has its own unpredictable dynamics. Zownir’s focus is, as always, based on his very own sympathy for the underdogs of this world. Known for his radical reports, he will once again illuminate the depths of everyday social life in America. In snapshots, photographic essays and environmental studies of outsiders and social underclasses, Miron Zownir is carrying on the tradition of his social documentary photography that he has dedicated himself to for over 35 years.

Not only the skid rows of San Francisco and LA and other urban molochs, as public spaces and mirror images of social life will be the topics of Zownirs photographic research. The photographer’s focus is also on the desolate situation of the "Native Americans" in the cities of the West and the life on the reservations.

In San Francisco, back then in his twenties, Zownir captured the gloomy and melancholy portrait of a proud and stoic Native American, wearing a crown of feathers, his eyes hidden in melancholic darkness and a mouth resembling a line of disappointment.

Thirty-six years later, the living conditions of the Native American have not improved at all. The racial discrimination is still ongoing. Especially in San Francisco this discrimination is very subtly, yet painfully obvious by social exclusion and an apparently invisible trauma of violence and racism inherited by generations. What becomes apparent are the fatal and inevitable consequences in an inhumane vicious cycle: drugs and alcohol abuse, homelessness. National data state that the San Francisco Bay Area has the highest percentage of Native Americans living with AIDS and HIV compared to any other region in the United States.

Twenty years ago Zownir left the USA where he had lived and photographed for almost 15 years. After many photo excursions through Russia, Germany, Poland, Bulgaria, France, Romania and the Ukraine, he is now once again drawn back to the United States.

Many say the America he knew no longer exists.

In his recently published photobook NYC RIP, showing exclusively photos from the 80’s, Lydia Lunch wrote in her introduction: “ The world contain within these pages speaks volumes to a time and place which no longer exist. Miron Zownir has captured New York City at the zenith of its mania.”

60 years after Robert Frank's ground-breaking legacy "The Americans" it is Zownir’s intention - with unbroken courage, creative flexibility, analogue and minimalistic means and the disquieting beauty of his visual language - to dive under America’s surface.  His portraits have always been encounters of a special kind, his city landscapes are magical and timeless; they challenge the viewer to take a closer look at society’s rejects and create an awareness of the contradictions, prejudices, exploitations and misunderstandings of our times.

Triumph of Photography

Fotomuseum Wintherthur, House of Photography/ Deichtorhallen Hamburg, Paris Photo, Photo London, Hardhitta Gallery Cologne, Centre de Cultura Contemporania Barcelona - Zownirs work has been exhibited in galleries and museums around the world. Ingo Taubhorn, curator of the House of Photography at Deichtorhallen in Hamburg, called Miron Zownir’s work a “triumph of photography”.  But Zownir won’t rest on his former achievements. Despite his success, he has stayed firmly rooted to his outsider beginning.

....more infos about the artist on www.mironzownir.com

Feel free to check our list of contribution perks on the right side of the page. Here are just some of them:


We completely understand that not everyone can donate, but if you find this project inspiring and you want to help make it happen, here are some FREE ways to do so: share this campaign on Facebook, tweet about it, share it in an email etc.etc... THANKS A LOT!

_________________________________________________________________________

GERMAN Version

HEADING WEST – Ein Fotoprojekt von MIRON ZOWNIR

Es ist das Wahlkampfjahr 2016. Ganz gleich wer gewinnt, ob Clinton oder Trump, Amerika steht vor einer Zerreißprobe, die die Nation in unüberbrückbare Gegensätze spalten wird.

Für viele Amerikaner ist es eine Wahl zwischen schlimm und schlimmer. In diese aufgeheizte Stimmung hinein, reist der Fotograf Miron Zownir in den amerikanischen Westen und visualisiert mit seiner Kamera kritische Fragen.

Jede Reise hat ihre eigene Dynamik des Unerwarteten. Das Spektrum der  Möglichkeiten ist riesig. Doch Zownirs Fokussierung ergibt sich aus seiner ureigenen Sympathie für die „Underdogs“ der Welt. Seine gewohnt radikale Berichterstattung, soll die Tiefen des alltäglichen sozialen Lebens in den USA beleuchten. Sie zeigt Momentaufnahmen, fotografische Essays und Milieustudien von Außenseitern und sozialen Unterschichten, ganz in der Tradition seiner sozialdokumentarischen Fotografie, der sich Miron Zownir schon seit mehr als 35 Jahren widmet.

Nicht nur die "skid rows" von San Francisco, LA und anderen Großstädten, als öffentliche Räume und Spiegelbilder des gesellschaftlichen Lebens, sollen im Zentrum von Zownirs fotografischen Recherchen stehen.  Ein Hauptaugenmerk legt der Fotograf auf die desolate Situation der „Native Americans“ in den westlichen Metropolen und den Reservaten.

1980 nahm Zownir, damals Mitte zwanzig,  in San Francisco das düster-melancholische Portrait eines Native American auf, der mit distanziert verschränkten Armen stolz, stoisch und einsam da steht und einen mit riesigen Federn verzierten Kopfschmuck trägt. Seine Augen liegen in tiefverschatteten Höhlen und sein Mund gleicht einem Bogen der Enttäuschung.

Sechsunddreißig Jahre später sind die Lebensumstände der Indianer nicht besser geworden. Die Rassendiskriminierung, ist bis heute nicht abgeschlossen. Besonders in San Francisco funktioniert sie sehr subtil durch Exklusion und einer scheinbaren Unsichtbarkeit des durch Gewalt und Rassismus über Generationen vererbten Traumas. Sichtbar sind nur die fatalen unabdingbaren Folgen in einem menschenunwürdigen Teufelskreislauf. Der Absturz in Drogen- und Alkoholmissbrauch, die Obdachlosigkeit. Die San Francisco Bay Area hat einen höheren Anteil an Native Americans mit AIDS/HIV, als irgendeine andere Region der Vereinigten Staaten.

Vor gut zwanzig Jahren verließ Zownir die USA, wo er zuvor fünfzehn Jahre gelebt und fotografiert hatte.  Nun zieht es ihn - nach vielen Fotorecherchen u.a. in Russland, Deutschland, Polen, Bulgarien, Frankreich, Rumänien und der Ukraine - wieder dorthin zurück.

Das Amerika, das er kannte, gibt es, so sagt man, nicht mehr.

Über Miron Zownirs kürzlich in dem Fotobuch NYC-RIP erschienen Fotografien aus den achtziger Jahren, schrieb Lydia Lunch: "Die auf diesen Seiten enthaltene Welt, spricht Bände über eine Zeit und einen Ort, die nicht mehr existieren. Miron Zownir hat New York auf dem Zenit des Wahnsinns eingefangen.“

60 Jahre nach Robert Franks bahnbrechenden Vermächtnis „The Americans“, will Zownir wieder, mit analogen, minimalistischen Mittel, vorurteilsfrei unter die Vorzeigeoberfläche Amerikas tauchen. Seine Portraits sind immer Begegnungen der besonderen Art, seine Stadtaufnahmen magisch und zeitlos aktuell; sie fordern den Betrachter zum Nachdenken heraus und schaffen eine Sensibilisierung für die Widersprüche, Vorurteile, Diskriminierungen und Missverständnisse unserer Zeit.

Triumph der Fotografie

Fotomuseum Wintherthur, Haus der Fotografie/ Deichtorhallen Hamburg, Paris Photo, Photo London, Hardhitta Gallery Köln, Centre de Cultura Contemporania Barcelona – Miron Zownirs Arbeiten wurde in Galerien und Museen auf der ganzen Welt ausgestellt. Als „Triumph der Fotografie“ betitelte Ingo Taubhorn, Kurator des Hauses für Photographie in den Hamburger Deichtorhallen, Miron Zownirs bisheriges fotografisches Werk. Doch auf diesem Höhepunkt möchte er nicht verweilen. Trotz seiner Erfolge fühlt er sich dem Außenseitertum immer noch tief verbunden.

mehr Infos unter www.mironzownir.com
